Let's break it down: Immigration Legal Aid in Ontario: Legal Aid Ontario (LAO) provides certificates for immigration and refugee law matters. The eligibility is based on both financial and merit criteria. Financial Eligibility: For immigration matters, the same financial eligibility rules apply as for other legal aid services. The applicant must meet the income and asset thresholds. Merit Test for Immigration Matters: The matter must have merit, meaning there must be a reasonable chance of success or a compelling humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) reason. Grounds for Immigration Legal Aid: Legal Aid Ontario may issue a certificate for immigration matters in the following circumstances (non-exhaustive list): Refugee protection claims Appeals at the Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB) Judicial reviews at the Federal Court H&C applications Detention reviews Certain family class sponsorship appeals Risk assessments Pre-removal risk assessments (PRRA) Resettlements Citizenship appeals Charter and Constitutional Arguments: If the immigration matter involves Charter rights, such as the right to life, liberty and security of the person (s.7), the right to be free from cruel and unusual treatment (s.12), or equality rights (s.15), these can strengthen the case for legal aid. In your case, the wrongful prosecution and its impact on your immigration status (loss of green card, inability to sponsor family, family separation) may engage Charter rights.
